llm.feedback: The draft is largely on‑target for the UST 10‑year but needs tightening to meet Argos standards: 1) **Handle mapping** – explicitly tag every claim with a canonical handle (e.g., “ust10y”, “fed_policy”, “us_inflation”, “us_core_cpi”, “us_pce”, “us_mortgage_rates”, “us_debt”, “us_treasury_supply”). 2) **Inline citations** – insert source IDs in parentheses immediately after each factual statement (e.g., (HYJA10SKI) after Fed‑cut reversal, (LF0UUL917) after mortgage‑rate proxy). 3) **Catalyst windows** – state the exact dates or periods driving the view: Fed cuts Sep 16‑17 2024, Fed balance‑sheet contraction ongoing (since Dec 2024), mortgage rates near 7% since Sep 2024, upcoming core CPI/PCE releases Q3 2025. 4) **Magnitude & horizon** – refine the base case to “ust10y yields 4.5 % ± 0.5 % over 12–18 months” and explicitly note the upward bias if the balance‑sheet contraction accelerates or inflation expectations rise. 5) **Invalidations** – list clear downside scenarios (e.g., Fed reversal to accommodative stance, large fiscal stimulus, sharp inflation spike) with their impact on ust10y. 6) **Confidence** – add a concise confidence rating (e.g., “moderate‑high”) and justify it with the structural break evidence. 7) **Remove drift** – eliminate any mention of non‑relevant assets (gold, silver, crypto) or unrelated commentary. 8) **Formatting** – ensure the paragraph follows Argos style: concise, action‑oriented, no fluff, and all claims backed by evidence.
